awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports use-inspired, team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and will produce deliverables of value to society in the near future.

This Convergence Accelerator Phase II project aims to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of reskilling America’s workforce. To accomplish this, the Competency Catalyst has two major deliverables. The first is an application called "Skillsync" that enables companies to communicate specific reskilling needs and helps colleges respond with accelerated programs that target them. The second is a “C2 platform” that describes and aligns job requirements and reskilling opportunities in terms of knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs). Skillsync is built on the C2 platform and replaces existing manual processes with direct, real-time communication between human resource departments and college programs. Skillsync will immediately improve the ability of companies to reskill their workforce, while the C2 platform will catalyze and support a larger ecosystem of workforce-related applications, including other Convergence Accelerator projects and national efforts focused on improving the talent pipeline. Skillsync and the C2 platform will be designed and developed by a multidisciplinary team of learning technologists, AI researchers, education and workforce development professionals, open data architects, and experts in competency-based training.  Skillsync will be piloted with multiple company-college pairs to upskill a diverse population of workers. After completing the pilots, the Competency Catalyst team plans to maintain the C2 platform as a public good, and to offer Skillsync as a subscription service paid for by companies and free to colleges. 

The Competency Catalyst will build on multiple enabling technologies, including (a) the Jill Watson AI-based conversational assistant from the Georgia Institute of Technology; (b) the Credential Engine’s open data infrastructure; and (c) digital competency extraction tools and the open-source Competency and Skills System (CaSS) developed by Eduworks. The development approach will include participatory research, human-centered design, rapid prototyping, and pilot testing. The C2 platform will programmatically ingest data from national sources and apply recent natural language understanding and machine learning methods to represent these data as structured sets of KSAs with relations and links to external resources. In Skillsync, these can be edited and ordered by importance to represent company needs. The C2 platform will offer an open alignment score service that Skillsync will use to analyze matches between desired KSAs and available educational and training resources. In addition, Skillsync users will be able to engage with Jill Watson to better understand how colleges view the skills that learners acquire. This will assist companies in defining their needs in terms that are meaningful to college partners.  Equity and bias issues will be considered throughout the design and development of the Skillsync and the C2 platform, including issues such as bias and fairness in AI and machine-learned models. The project will also research the relative contributions of AI, enhanced digital communication, and socio-technological behavioral change to improving company-college reskilling partnerships. Anticipated contributions include new techniques for evaluating and aligning jobs and training based on KSAs and a new public open data resource consisting of the KSAs associated with national repositories of jobs, course syllabi, credentials, and educational resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the Competency Catalyst were: (1) help employers communicate upskilling needs to college continuing education departments; (2) help colleges respond with offerings that meet those needs; (3) provide more opportunities to under-served worker populations by focusing on skills rather than degrees and past job titles; and (4) improve training efficiency and effectiveness by aligning college offerings with employer skills requirements. To accomplish these goals the project team developed a web app, called SkillSync, that enables employers to create and transmit training requests to colleges and enables colleges to respond with training proposals. Training requests include prioritized lists of desired skills. Skills can be entered manually, selected from existing skills frameworks, or extracted from job descriptions using artificial intelligence (AI). Colleges create training proposals with the aid of AI that identifies which desired skills are covered by existing courses and that scores the alignment between one or more courses and the skills in a training request. Training proposals can involve existing courses or new offerings created by combining or modifying multiple courses. 

In joint work with the Learning Environments with Augmentation and Robotics for Next-gen Emergency Responders (LEARNER - NSF #2033592) project, functionality was developed that allows employers, training providers, and workers to generate skills profiles for jobs, learning opportunities, and individuals. Skills profiles identify what level of which skills are needed for a job, possessed by a worker, or attainable from a course or other learning experience. A joint Skills-based Talent Ecosystem Platform for UPskilling (STEP-UP) proof-of-concept shows how skills profiles can be used by employers to find potential workers and by workers to see their skill gaps and find training opportunities to fill them. STEP-UP offers links to online training with varying levels of interactivity and immersiveness that automatically reports skills and updates worker profiles upon completion. 

SkillSync and STEP-UP are supported by AI services that can be accessed via Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) for use in other applications as well as SkillSync. These are used to auto-generate portions of skills profiles from job descriptions, course descriptions, and résumés, and to measure alignment between learning opportunities and prioritized lists of skills. Job skills profiles, course skill profiles, and these AI services are now used in Job Skills for In-Demand Employment (JobSIDE), an application developed for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation’s Talent Pipeline Management (TPM) initiative. JobSIDE lets company collaboratives publish job skills profiles for jobs, roles, and job functions with reference to Standard Occupation Classification (SOC) codes, North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes, and geographies, and enables colleges to align courses with these profiles. 

This project resulted in significant innovations and contributions in the areas of AI and technology that supports talent pipeline ecosystems. AI innovations included: (1) methods for debiasing language models and skills statements extracted from unstructured text; (2) services that remove “company identifiable information” from job postings; (3) AI that computes an alignment score between course materials and desired skill sets; and (4) methods for reducing the size of large language models (LLMs) as well as the effort required to update them without impacting their performance. The AI used in the project was originally based on BERT and related transformer methods and rapidly evolved to take advantage of new methods as they emerged.  These methods are being used in unrelated applications to reduce AI training and deployment costs while improving accuracy and reducing bias.

Technology innovations include (1) digitization of the processes and workflows used by employers and colleges to work together to upskill incumbent workers and (2) a STEP-UP proof of concept that demonstrates how skills profiles that are based on curated skills frameworks and that are generated with automated skills extraction tools can support workers, employers, and training providers. The project team also investigated the use of a conversational AI agent based on Georgia Tech’s Jill Watson. Originally conceived as an intelligent guide, the team concluded that the best use of such an agent was to answer questions about the concepts and technology used by the application rather than guide the user through it.

Finally, the project resulted in scalable methods developed for aligning college continuing education offerings with in-demand skills needs and technology for communicating skills needs and offerings and for managing multiple types of skills profiles. These methods support more accurate and equitable skills-based hiring and close communication gaps between employers and colleges and promise to have a growing impact. The TPM initiative referenced above includes 3,000 employers and educational institutions across the United States, and the project team continues to work with the DXtera Institute, the National Association of State Workforce Agencies, the Business-Higher Education Forum, UPCEA, WorkCred, and other partners on a variety of AI-assisted skills trend analysis, course analysis, and micro-credentialing initiatives.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2024
Modified by: Robert Robson
